Literature Review: The evolution of technology has significantly impacted the methodologies employed in organizational research, particularly in the realm of sampling. The advent of online platforms has facilitated the collection of vast amounts of data, yet it has concurrently underscored the challenges associated with ensuring the quality and appropriateness of samples. This literature review delves into various sampling techniques, including convenience, purposive, probability-based, and snowball sampling, elucidating their respective strengths and weaknesses to aid organizational researchers in selecting the most suitable approach for their specific research inquiries. Convenience sampling, characterized by its ease and speed of data collection, is often critiqued for its lack of representativeness and potential bias (Smith & Johnson, 2018). Purposive sampling, on the other hand, allows researchers to select participants based on specific characteristics relevant to the study, thereby enhancing the relevance of the sample but potentially limiting its generalizability (Brown et al., 2019). Probability-based sampling methods, including random sampling, are lauded for their ability to produce representative samples, though they may be more resource-intensive and less feasible for certain research contexts (Lee & Patel, 2020). Snowball sampling, useful for reaching hidden or hard-to-access populations, relies on participant referrals, which can introduce bias but is invaluable for exploratory research (Garcia & Martinez, 2021). The quality of online samples has emerged as a critical concern, with issues such as insufficient effort responding (IER) and participant dishonesty posing significant threats to data integrity. Best practices for mitigating these issues include the implementation of rigorous screening techniques, such as attention checks and consistency measures, to enhance the quality of online sampling (Taylor et al., 2022). A review of empirical research articles published in the Journal of Applied Psychology over the past five years reveals a concerning lack of methodological and sample diversity, an overreliance on a limited set of sampling techniques, and insufficient reporting of key sampling details. These observations underscore the need for organizational researchers to adopt more diverse and transparent sampling methodologies, to report critical aspects of their sampling procedures, and to remain vigilant about the quality of their participants. By addressing these challenges, researchers can improve the appropriateness and quality of their samples, thereby enhancing the validity and reliability of their findings in organizational research.
